    # Phase¬†6 Thermo: Measurement and Calibration
    
    ## Background
    
    Heat moves from hotter objects to colder ones, and the rate of energy transfer per unit area and unit time is called the heat flux. Fourier‚Äôs law states that the flux is proportional to the negative of the temperature gradient; in one dimension the law reads¬†œïq=‚àíkdTdxœïq‚Äã=‚àíkdxdT‚Äã, where¬†kk¬†is the thermal conductivity of the material[en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heat_flux#:~:text=For%20most%20solids%20%20in,adequately%20described%20by%20Fourier%27s%20law). Measuring heat flux is important because it determines how much energy is exchanged between systems and therefore how their entropy changes. The entropy change of a system due to a heat transfer¬†QQ¬†at temperature¬†TT¬†is¬†ŒîS=Q/TŒîS=Q/T; for processes with small temperature variations this approximation holds well[physics.bu.edu](https://physics.bu.edu/~redner/211-sp06/class-engines/class25_secondlaw.html#:~:text=Entropy%20changes%20whenever%20there%20is,Expressed%20as%20an%20integral). In the toy Œ©‚Äëmodel, heat transfer and entropy production correspond to the communication term¬†C(Scomm‚àíŒª‚Ä≤Isem)C(Scomm‚Äã‚àíŒª‚Ä≤Isem‚Äã), so obtaining reliable flux and entropy measurements is essential for calibrating Œª‚Ä≤.
    
    ## Heat‚ÄëFlux Measurement Methods
    
    1. **Known thermal conductivity.**¬†When the thermal conductivity¬†kk¬†and thickness¬†xx¬†of a material are known, one can measure the temperature difference across the material and use Fourier‚Äôs law to compute the heat flux. This indirect method is analogous to measuring an electric current via a known resistor: by measuring the temperature drop across a known thermal resistance, one obtains the flux[en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heat_flux#:~:text=A%20commonly%20known%2C%20but%20often,can%20then%20be%20indirectly%20calculated). Accurate values of¬†kk¬†and¬†xx¬†are required, which can be difficult for heterogeneous materials[en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heat_flux#:~:text=Usually%20this%20method%20is%20difficult,flux%20can%20then%20be%20indirectly).
        
    2. **Unknown thermal conductivity.**¬†When¬†kk¬†is unknown or impractical to measure, a heat‚Äëflux sensor (often a thermopile) can be used to directly measure the energy flow. Such sensors produce a voltage proportional to the temperature difference across a calibrated thermal resistance and therefore provide heat‚Äëflux readings without needing¬†kk[en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heat_flux#:~:text=A%20second%20method%20of%20measuring,value%20of%20thermal%20resistance%20or). The sensor output must be calibrated to relate the micro‚Äëvolt signal to heat flux in¬†W‚Äâm‚àí2Wm‚àí2[en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heat_flux#:~:text=A%20second%20method%20of%20measuring,value%20of%20thermal%20resistance%20or).
        
    
    ## Entropy‚ÄëChange Calculation
    
    Entropy is a state function, but its change is easy to compute when heat flows at (or near) a constant temperature. For a small amount of heat transfer¬†dQdQ¬†at temperature¬†TT, the entropy change is¬†dS=dQ/TdS=dQ/T. Integrating yields¬†ŒîS=Q/TavgŒîS=Q/Tavg‚Äã¬†when the temperature varies only slightly during the exchange[physics.bu.edu](https://physics.bu.edu/~redner/211-sp06/class-engines/class25_secondlaw.html#:~:text=Entropy%20changes%20whenever%20there%20is,Expressed%20as%20an%20integral). In the two‚Äëbody problem (e.g. two water containers), the entropy increase in the colder body is¬†ŒîScold=Q/TcoldŒîScold‚Äã=Q/Tcold‚Äã¬†and the entropy decrease in the hotter body is¬†‚àíQ/Thot‚àíQ/Thot‚Äã; summing them gives the net entropy production of the process[physics.bu.edu](https://physics.bu.edu/~redner/211-sp06/class-engines/class25_secondlaw.html#:~:text=Entropy%20changes%20whenever%20there%20is,Expressed%20as%20an%20integral).

Integrate¬†œïq(t)œïq‚Äã(t)¬†over area and time to obtain the total heat transferred¬†Q=‚à´0Œîtœïq(t)A‚ÄâdtQ=‚à´0Œît‚Äãœïq‚Äã(t)Adt.

If the experiment involves information being transmitted (e.g. digital signals), measure the mutual information¬†IsemIsem‚Äã¬†and compute the energy cost per meaningful bit. Finally, compute¬†Œ©Œ©¬†at each time point and verify that it decreases toward zero as the system approaches equilibrium.
        
    
    ## Calibration and Parameter Extraction
    
    Once heat‚Äëflux data and entropy production are obtained, one can calibrate Œª‚Ä≤ and other parameters in the Œ© model by solving¬†C(Scomm‚àíŒª‚Ä≤Isem)C(Scomm‚Äã‚àíŒª‚Ä≤Isem‚Äã)¬†to match the measured energy flow.     # Phase¬†6 AI: Measurement and Calibration
    
    ## Background
    
    Training modern machine‚Äëlearning models consumes significant energy, and measuring that consumption is a prerequisite for quantifying the energetic cost of information processing. Several software and hardware tools exist for estimating the energy and carbon footprint of AI workloads. These range from integrated Python packages to server‚Äëside monitoring systems and physical wattmeters. The Œ© framework links energy use to information: the entropy rate of the communication channel¬†ScommScomm‚Äã¬†and the semantic information rate¬†IsemIsem‚Äã¬†must be measured alongside the energy used to process data and train models.
    
    ## Measuring Energy Consumption
    
    Research from Bouza et¬†al. (2023) reviews tools that measure or estimate energy consumption and CO‚ÇÇ‚Äëequivalent emissions for deep‚Äëlearning models[pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10661046/#:~:text=This%20section%20explains%20how%20tools,own%20way%20of%20estimating%20the). These tools fall into three categories:
    
    - **Embedded software packages (Python libraries).**¬†Packages such as CodeCarbon, Eco2AI, CarbonTracker, EIT and MLCO‚ÇÇ can be integrated into machine‚Äëlearning code to estimate the energy used by CPUs, GPUs and memory. They obtain power measurements from hardware sensors (e.g. RAPL files or the NVIDIA¬†`pynvml`¬†interface) or fall back to thermal design power (TDP) models when sensors are unavailable[pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10661046/#:~:text=5,yes%20yes%20yes%20no%20no). Measurements are taken at regular intervals (typically every 10‚Äì15¬†s) to compute the average power draw[pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10661046/#:~:text=A%20transversal%20concept%20to%20all,processes%20also%20using%20said%20resource).
        
    - **Online calculators and server‚Äëside tools.**¬†Tools like Green‚ÄëAlgorithms provide web forms or server‚Äëside daemons that estimate total energy consumption for a job or a machine. These tools can be used without modifying code and are useful in high‚Äëperformance computing environments[pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10661046/#:~:text=This%20section%20explains%20how%20tools,own%20way%20of%20estimating%20the).
        
    - **Physical wattmeters.**¬†When more precise measurements are required, wattmeters can be attached to the power supply of a machine to capture the total energy draw. Physical measurements can be combined with usage factors‚Äîthe proportion of CPU/GPU use attributable to a given process‚Äîto allocate energy consumption to specific training runs[pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10661046/#:~:text=A%20transversal%20concept%20to%20all,processes%20also%20using%20said%20resource).
        
    
    Additional factors include the efficiency of the data center where training occurs. The power‚Äëusage effectiveness (PUE) quantifies how much extra energy is needed for cooling, lighting and other overhead; some tools allow users to configure PUE values[pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10661046/#:~:text=When%20the%20machine%20is%20in,PUE). When models are trained in cloud environments, the energy used by shared infrastructure must be attributed appropriately using usage factors[pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10661046/#:~:text=A%20transversal%20concept%20to%20all,processes%20also%20using%20said%20resource).
    
    ## Measuring Semantic Information
    
    The semantic gain of a model can be quantified using mutual information. Mutual information¬†I(X;Y)I(X;Y)¬†between random variables¬†XX¬†and¬†YY¬†is defined as the Kullback‚ÄìLeibler divergence between their joint distribution and the product of their marginals[en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutual_information#:~:text=Mutual%20Information%20is%20also%20known,as%20information%20gain). In terms of entropy,¬†I(X;Y)=H(X)‚àíH(X‚à£Y)=H(Y)‚àíH(Y‚à£X)I(X;Y)=H(X)‚àíH(X‚à£Y)=H(Y)‚àíH(Y‚à£X)[en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutual_information#:~:text=%5BImage%2027%3A%20%7B%5Cdisplaystyle%20I%28X%3BY%29%3DH%28X%29). For discrete variables, mutual information is computed by summing¬†PX,Y(x,y)log‚Å°(PX,Y(x,y)/(PX(x)PY(y)))PX,Y‚Äã(x,y)log(PX,Y‚Äã(x,y)/(PX‚Äã(x)PY‚Äã(y)))¬†over all pairs¬†(x,y)(x,y)[en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutual_information#:~:text=,3%20%5D%3A%2020). When the log base¬†2 is used, the result is measured in bits[en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutual_information#:~:text=If%20the%20natural%20logarithm%20,as%20the%20ban%20or%20the).
    
    In the AI domain,¬†IsemIsem‚Äã¬†can represent the reduction in uncertainty about labels given the model‚Äôs predictions or the gain in performance on a downstream task. To estimate¬†IsemIsem‚Äã¬†one may:
    
    - **Compute mutual information between inputs and labels**¬†using kernel density estimators or discrete histograms. This measures how much the model‚Äôs updates (or communication between federated learners) convey about the training labels.
        
    - **Use task‚Äëspecific metrics (e.g. accuracy or F1‚Äëscore)**¬†and convert performance improvements into bits via Fano‚Äôs inequality or surrogate mutual‚Äëinformation estimators.
        
    - **Assess semantic alignment in generative models**¬†by computing the mutual information between generated outputs and desired semantics.
        
    
    The raw communication entropy rate¬†ScommScomm‚Äã¬†corresponds to the bit rate of data exchanged (e.g. gradients or model parameters) and is measured by counting transmitted bits per unit time. Landauer‚Äôs principle then maps each erased bit to an energy cost of¬†kBTln‚Å°2kB‚ÄãTln2¬†joules.
    
    ## Proposed Measurement Procedure
    
    1. **Instrumentation.**¬†Integrate a measurement package (e.g. CodeCarbon) into the training code or set up a monitoring daemon on the training server. Ensure the package can access CPU/GPU sensors or provide TDP models. Configure the sampling interval (e.g. 10¬†s)[pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10661046/#:~:text=A%20transversal%20concept%20to%20all,processes%20also%20using%20said%20resource)¬†and set the appropriate PUE factor if training in a data center[pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10661046/#:~:text=When%20the%20machine%20is%20in,PUE).
        
    2. **Record energy.**¬†Start the measurement before training begins. At each sampling interval, record the instantaneous power consumption of CPU, GPU and memory. Multiply power by the interval length to obtain energy (Wh) and sum over time to get total energy consumption for the training run.
        
    3. **Calculate usage factors.**¬†When multiple processes run on the same hardware, compute the fraction of each resource used by the training job (e.g. CPU utilization) and scale the measured power accordingly[pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10661046/#:~:text=A%20transversal%20concept%20to%20all,processes%20also%20using%20said%20resource). If usage factors are unknown, assume 100% as a conservative upper bound.
        
    4. **Measure communication entropy¬†ScommScomm‚Äã.**¬†For federated or distributed training, log the size (in bits) of gradients or parameters transmitted per round and divide by the time between rounds to obtain the bit rate. Convert to entropy rate by accounting for compression schemes and error‚Äëcorrecting overhead.
        
    5. **Measure semantic information¬†IsemIsem‚Äã.**¬†After each training round or epoch, estimate the mutual information between the model parameters (or predictions) and the ground‚Äëtruth labels using the methods described above. Record the information gain per unit time.
        
    6. **Compute Œ© and calibrate Œª‚Ä≤.**¬†Convert the bit rates to energy rates via Landauer‚Äôs principle.     # Phase¬†6 Social: Measurement and Calibration
    
    ## Background
    
    Digital social platforms enable billions of interactions every day. Behind each post, video stream or message is a network of servers and data centers that consume electricity. Articles on the environmental cost of social media note that platforms like Facebook, Instagram and TikTok rely on data‚Äëcenter infrastructure powered by electricity, much of which is generated from carbon‚Äëintensive sources[greenly.earth](https://greenly.earth/en-us/leaf-media/data-stories/the-hidden-environmental-cost-of-social-media#:~:text=Social%20media%20has%20transformed%20the,to%20keep%20these%20platforms%20running). Every digital action therefore contributes to global emissions[greenly.earth](https://greenly.earth/en-us/leaf-media/data-stories/the-hidden-environmental-cost-of-social-media#:~:text=environmental%20cost%3A%20the%20energy%20required,to%20keep%20these%20platforms%20running). More broadly, U.S. data centers consumed about 183¬†TWh of electricity in¬†2024‚Äîover 4% of national demand‚Äîand this consumption is expected to more than double by 2030[pewresearch.org](https://www.pewresearch.org/short-reads/2025/10/24/what-we-know-about-energy-use-at-us-data-centers-amid-the-ai-boom/#:~:text=U,to%20426%20TWh). Around 60% of a data center‚Äôs electricity powers servers, particularly the powerful chips used for AI workloads[pewresearch.org](https://www.pewresearch.org/short-reads/2025/10/24/what-we-know-about-energy-use-at-us-data-centers-amid-the-ai-boom/#:~:text=,for%20at%20data%20centers).
    
    Social interactions not only require energy but also produce and exchange information. When users share high‚Äëquality, semantically meaningful content, they may cooperate more and the system may perform more useful work per unit energy. The Œ© framework models these dynamics via the communication flux¬†CC, communication entropy rate¬†ScommScomm‚Äã¬†and semantic information rate¬†IsemIsem‚Äã.
    
    ## Measuring Energy Consumption in Social Systems
    
    To study Œ© in a social context, one needs to measure how much energy is consumed by the platform and by end‚Äëusers. At the platform level, energy use can be estimated by combining data‚Äëcenter energy metrics with user activity:
    
    - **Data‚Äëcenter energy statistics.**¬†Obtain server‚Äëlevel power measurements from the platform provider. The Pew Research Center reports that data centers use 60¬†% of their electricity to power servers[pewresearch.org](https://www.pewresearch.org/short-reads/2025/10/24/what-we-know-about-energy-use-at-us-data-centers-amid-the-ai-boom/#:~:text=,for%20at%20data%20centers); remaining energy powers cooling and other infrastructure. Consumption per user or per interaction can be estimated by dividing total server energy by the number of active users or requests.
        
    - **User‚Äëside energy.**¬†Recognize that users themselves consume energy when accessing social platforms. The Hidden Environmental Cost of Social Media notes that emissions come not only from corporate operations but also from the energy used by billions of users when they stream videos or run power‚Äëhungry devices[greenly.earth](https://greenly.earth/en-us/leaf-media/data-stories/the-hidden-environmental-cost-of-social-media#:~:text=In%20response%2C%20many%20of%20the,intensive%20devices%20such%20as%20laptops). Approximate user‚Äëside energy by measuring average device power consumption during platform use and scaling by session duration.
        
    
    ## Proposed Experiment for the Social Domain
    
    The following A/B‚Äëstyle experiment can be conducted within a social platform to test how information quality affects cooperation and energy use:
    
    1. **Participant groups.**¬†Recruit users or simulate agents on a social platform. Randomly assign them to two groups (A¬†and¬†B). Group¬†A receives high‚Äëquality, semantically rich information streams, while group¬†B receives lower‚Äëquality or noisy information.
        
    2. **Instrumentation.**¬†Instrument the platform‚Äôs backend to log energy use per request. Use server monitoring tools to record total energy consumption and allocate it to groups based on the number of requests they generate. At the same time, instrument client devices (or estimate typical device power) to approximate user‚Äëside energy consumption for each session.
        
    3. **Measure communication entropy.**¬†For each group, record the total amount of data exchanged (posts, messages, video minutes) over time. Compute¬†ScommScomm‚Äã¬†by converting data volume to bits per second and adjusting for compression or protocol overhead.
        
    4. **Measure semantic information and cooperation.**¬†Assess the semantic quality of content using mutual information or natural‚Äëlanguage metrics (e.g. topic relevance, factual accuracy). Quantify cooperative behaviour via metrics such as the number of constructive comments, successful collaborations or completion of shared tasks.
        
    5. **Compute Œ© and compare groups.**¬†For each group, calculate energy used (servers¬†+ clients), communication entropy rate and semantic information rate. Use these to compute¬†Œ©=E‚àíC(Scomm‚àíŒª‚Ä≤Isem)+‚Ä¶Œ©=E‚àíC(Scomm‚Äã‚àíŒª‚Ä≤Isem‚Äã)+‚Ä¶. If the Œ© framework is correct, the group receiving higher‚Äëquality information should exhibit lower Œ© (more cooperation and semantic efficiency) and Œ© should decrease over time as users align their actions.
        
    
    ## Calibration and Parameter Extraction
    
    After collecting data, estimate Œª‚Ä≤ as the ratio of semantic information to raw communication entropy:¬†Œª‚Ä≤=Isem/ScommŒª‚Ä≤=Isem‚Äã/Scomm‚Äã. Fit other Œ© parameters using gradient‚Äëbased methods to ensure that the model reproduces the observed decline of Œ© in the high‚Äëquality information group. This experiment will also reveal how improvements in content quality or platform efficiency (e.g. migrating to renewable energy) reduce energy consumption per meaningful interaction.

    This document identifies key risks associated with the design, measurement,

    mitigation strategies. Users and developers should review these risks  
    before applying the framework to real systems.

    |**Measurement uncertainty**|Estimates of¬†ScommScomm‚Äã¬†and¬†IsemIsem‚Äã¬†rely on finite sampling and approximate estimators.     |**Model parameter instability**|Poor choices of¬†Œ±,Œ≤,Œ¥Œ±,Œ≤,Œ¥¬†(e.g.¬†Œ¥‚â§0Œ¥‚â§0) or large time steps in gradient flows can render Œ© unbounded below or cause numerical blow‚Äëup.|Simulation may diverge, invalidating experiments.|Use the ‚ÄúMinimal, Stable Œ©‚Äù form with¬†Œ¥>0Œ¥>0¬†and positive quadratic coefficients; follow recommended step sizes; verify monotonic decrease of Œ© numerically before running large experiments.|
    |**Privacy and data sensitivity**|Measuring semantic information can involve personal or sensitive data; analysing datasets without proper anonymization may expose individuals to re‚Äëidentification or inference attacks. Research shows that re‚Äëidentification and sensitive inference risks must be evaluated when publishing or processing data[oaepublish.com](https://www.oaepublish.com/articles/jsss.2020.20#:~:text=Aim%3A%20Data%20anonymization%20aims%20to,publishing%20data%20with%20a%20high).|Violations of privacy regulations, loss of user trust, or harm to data subjects.|Apply anonymization and differential privacy techniques; limit access to raw data; aggregate results; assess re-identification risk prior to analysis; follow relevant data protection laws and ethics guidelines.|
    |**Utility‚Äìprivacy trade‚Äëoff**|In distributed learning and federated settings, attackers can infer sensitive information from shared gradients; mutual information can quantify utility and privacy trade‚Äëoffs[pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC9498028/#:~:text=In%20distributed%20machine%20learning%20,Finally%2C%20the).|Over‚Äëemphasis on privacy may degrade model performance; too little noise may leak data.|Use differential privacy mechanisms with carefully chosen noise variance; analyse mutual information to balance utility and privacy; allow users to set privacy budgets appropriate to their context.|

High‚Äëentropy communications may increase power usage.|Increased operational costs and carbon footprint.|Monitor energy usage (e.g. with CodeCarbon/Eco2AI); design experiments to minimise unnecessary computation; consider renewable energy sources; factor energy costs into the evaluation of Œ©.|

    # Œ© Project User Guide
    
    Welcome to the Œ© (_Omega_) framework. This guide explains how to set up  
    the environment, run the provided scripts, interpret results and use the  
    documentation site. It assumes basic familiarity with Python and the  
    command line.
    
    ## 1. Installation and setup
    
    1. **Clone or extract the repository.**¬†If you received a ZIP archive  
        (`omega_project_phaseX.zip`), unpack it into a directory of your  
        choice.
        
    2. **Install Python 3.11 or later.**¬†Most scripts rely on standard  
        scientific libraries (NumPy, Matplotlib, PyYAML). You can install  
        dependencies via¬†`pip`:
        
        `pip install numpy matplotlib pyyaml`
        
    3. **Set the Python path (optional).**¬†The project uses a  
        package structure (`omega_project`). When running scripts from the  
        repository root, set the¬†`PYTHONPATH`¬†environment variable:
        
        `export PYTHONPATH="$(pwd)"`
        
    
    ## 2. Repository structure
    
    `omega_project/   configs/          # YAML configuration files for simulations   data/             # Sample signal and dataset for measurement demos   docs/             # MkDocs documentation pages   experiments/      # Outputs from simulations and analyses   notebooks/        # Jupyter notebooks (optional, not required)   reports/          # Example reports from Phase¬†6   scripts/          # Executable Python scripts   spec/             # Formal specifications (Œ© functional, units, GR tensor)   tests/            # Unit tests risk_register.md    # Identified risks and mitigations user_guide.md       # This guide mkdocs.yml          # Configuration for documentation site repro.sh            # Reproducibility script`
    
    ### Key components
    
    - **`spec/units_and_symbols.md`**¬†defines all symbols, units and constants.
        
    - **`spec/omega_minimal.md`**¬†describes the minimal stable form of the Œ©  
        functional and its parameters.
        
    - **`scripts/nondim.py`**¬†converts variables to nondimensional form based  
        on user‚Äësupplied scales (see¬†`configs/nondim.yaml`).
        
    - **`scripts/entropy_rate.py`**¬†computes the communication entropy rate  
        ScommScomm‚Äã¬†from a digital signal file.
        
    - **`scripts/semantic_mi.py`**¬†estimates the semantic information rate  
        IsemIsem‚Äã¬†via mutual information between variables in a dataset.
        
    - **`scripts/gradflow.py`**¬†and¬†**`scripts/prox_step.py`**¬†perform  
        gradient and proximal dynamics for the communication flux¬†CC.
        
    - **`scripts/gr_check.py`**¬†verifies the conservation of the communication  
        stress‚Äìenergy tensor in a relativistic setting.
        
    - **`scripts/plot_omega.py`**¬†reads a CSV trace and produces a graph of  
        Œ© versus time.
        
    - **`repro.sh`**¬†orchestrates a simple reproducible experiment and plots  
        Œ©(t).
        
    - **`docs/`**¬†contains the documentation site; see section¬†5 for usage.
        
    
    ## 3. Measurement pipeline
    
    1. **Prepare your data.**¬†To compute¬†ScommScomm‚Äã, provide a raw  
        signal file where each sample is an integer or symbol. To compute  
        IsemIsem‚Äã, provide a CSV file with columns representing input  
        variables and target labels.
        
    2. **Compute communication entropy:**
        
        `python -m omega_project.scripts.entropy_rate \   --input path/to/signal.txt \   --sample_rate 1000 \   --temperature 300 \   --window 4096 \   --output s_comm.json`
        
        This will estimate the entropy rate in bits per second and convert it  
        to joules per second using¬†Ebit=kBTln‚Å°2Ebit‚Äã=kB‚ÄãTln2. Adjust  
        `sample_rate`¬†and¬†`temperature`¬†to match your system.
        
    3. **Compute semantic information:**
        
        `python -m omega_project.scripts.semantic_mi \   --dataset path/to/dataset.csv \   --columns X,Y \   --bins 20 \   --output i_sem.json`
        
        The script will estimate the mutual information between columns¬†`X`  
        and¬†`Y`. Increase the number of bins for finer resolution. You can  
        normalise by sample time to obtain a rate.
        
    4. **Calibrate¬†Œª‚Ä≤Œª‚Ä≤.**¬†Use your estimates of¬†ScommScomm‚Äã  
        and¬†IsemIsem‚Äã¬†to compute the ratio¬†Œª‚Ä≤=Isem/ScommŒª‚Ä≤=Isem‚Äã/Scomm‚Äã.  
        Store this value in a configuration file (see¬†`configs/calib_lambda.yaml`)  
        for use in simulations.
        
    
    ## 4. Simulating dynamics
    
    To explore how Œ© evolves over time, run the gradient or proximal  
    simulation scripts. For example:
    
    `# Gradient flow simulation python -m omega_project.scripts.gradflow \   --steps 200 --dt 0.01 --initial 1.0 \   --alpha 1.0 --delta 1.0 --beta 0.5 --sigma 1.0 \   --lambda_prime 0.001 --S_comm 0.5 --I_sem 0.4 \   --output experiments/gradflow.csv  # Proximal gradient simulation python -m omega_project.scripts.prox_step \   --steps 200 --eta 0.1 --initial 1.0 \   --alpha 1.0 --delta 1.0 --beta 0.5 --sigma 1.0 \   --lambda_prime 0.001 --S_comm 0.5 --I_sem 0.4 \   --output experiments/prox.csv`
    
    After running a simulation, you can visualise Œ©(t) using  
    `scripts/plot_omega.py`:
    
    `python -m omega_project.scripts.plot_omega \   --input experiments/gradflow.csv \   --output experiments/omega.png`
    
    ## 5. Documentation site
    
    The project includes a MkDocs site that gathers specifications,  
    explanations and examples. To build and preview the site locally, run:
    
    `pip install mkdocs mkdocs serve`
    
    Then navigate to¬†`http://localhost:8000`¬†in your browser. The site  
    contains pages on the Omega equation, measurement pipelines, dynamics  
    and the GR tensor, along with embedded figures.
    
    ## 6. Reproducibility script
    
    The¬†`repro.sh`¬†script provides a turnkey reproduction of a simple  
    experiment. It runs a gradient flow with fixed parameters and  
    generates a CSV and PNG plot in¬†`omega_project/experiments/repro/`.
    
    To execute the script from the repository root:
    
    `bash repro.sh`
    
    The script sets up the Python path, runs the simulation via  
    `gradflow.py`¬†and then calls¬†`plot_omega.py`¬†to create¬†`omega.png`. Check  
    the resulting CSV and PNG to verify that Œ© decreases monotonically.
    
    ## 7. Additional tools
    
    - **GR tensor check:**¬†Verify conservation of the communication  
        stress‚Äìenergy tensor by running
        
        `python -m omega_project.scripts.gr_check --n 400 --tol 1e-3`
        
        The script prints the maximum divergence and reports whether the  
        conservation law holds within the specified tolerance.
        
    - **Toy models:**¬†Explore the parameter space using¬†`run_toy.py`¬†and  
        configuration files under¬†`configs/`. For example:
        
        `python -m omega_project.scripts.run_toy \   --config omega_project/configs/minimal.yaml \   --out experiments/sweep_results.csv`
        
        Review the CSV to identify parameter regimes where Œ© decreases and  
        converges.
        
    
    ## 8. Data and privacy considerations
    
    When working with real data, ensure that you anonymize or aggregate  
    personal information. Researchers caution that evaluating  
    re‚Äëidentification and inference risks is essential when publishing  
    datasets[oaepublish.com](https://www.oaepublish.com/articles/jsss.2020.20#:~:text=Aim%3A%20Data%20anonymization%20aims%20to,publishing%20data%20with%20a%20high). If using distributed learning or  
    federated settings, be aware that attackers may infer sensitive  
    information from gradients; mutual information can be used to analyse  
    utility‚Äìprivacy trade‚Äëoffs and to choose noise levels appropriately[pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC9498028/#:~:text=In%20distributed%20machine%20learning%20,Finally%2C%20the).
    
    ## 9. Contributing
    
    Contributions are welcome! Please open issues or pull requests to

# Omega Project

This repository collects specifications and initial scaffolding for implementing
a **minimal, stable Omega functional** that combines thermodynamics,
information theory, quantum‚Äêfield inspired dynamics and strategic interactions.

## Contents

- `spec/units_and_symbols.md` ‚Äî defines all variables used in the functional and their units.
- `spec/omega_minimal.md` ‚Äî describes the proposed minimal stable form of the Omega functional and the constraints on its parameters.
- `pyproject.toml` ‚Äî Python project configuration with Poetry as the build tool and Ruff, Black and pytest configured for development.
- `.pre-commit-config.yaml` ‚Äî a pre‚Äëcommit configuration to automatically format and lint code.

## Getting started

1. Install dependencies and pre-commit hooks:

   ```bash
   pip install poetry
   poetry install
   pre-commit install
   ```

2. Run tests and linting:

   ```bash
   poetry run pytest
   pre-commit run --all-files
   ```

This repository is intended as the starting point for the research phases
outlined in earlier discussions.  See `spec/omega_minimal.md` for the
functional definition and Phase 0 plan.  Later phases will add code under
`scripts/`, configuration files under `configs/` and notebooks under
`notebooks/`.

# Minimal Stable Omega Functional

This document describes the minimal form of the ‚Ñ¶ (Omega) functional that is
bounded below and suitable for gradient‚Äìflow dynamics.  The goal is to combine
thermodynamic, informational and field-theoretic contributions into a single
Lyapunov‚Äêlike function for complex systems.  A stable form ensures that the
functional does not run off to negative infinity and can serve as a
Lyapunov function for dynamical evolution.

## Functional definition

We propose the following form for the Omega functional:

\[
\Omega = E \; - \; C\,\bigl(S_{\mathrm{comm}} - \lambda'\,I_{\mathrm{sem}}\bigr)
\; + \; \tfrac{\alpha}{2} C^2
\; + \; \tfrac{\delta}{4} C^4
\; + \; \hbar_C |\Psi_C|^2
\; + \; \kappa\,\Vert\nabla \Psi_C\Vert^2
\; + \; \tfrac{\beta\sigma}{2}\,C^2.
\]

### Terms

- **E** ‚Äî total energy available to or injected into the system.
- **C¬†(S_comm¬†‚àí¬†Œª‚Ä≤¬†I_sem)** ‚Äî coupling between communication flux and the entropy/semantic information content of the channel.  The term penalises high entropy and rewards meaningful information, weighted by the fraction Œª‚Ä≤ of bits carrying semantics.
- **(Œ±¬†/¬†2)¬†C¬≤** ‚Äî quadratic contribution to the potential.  This term, combined with Œ≤œÉC¬≤ below, ensures convexity near the origin.  The coefficients are tuned such that the sum of quadratic terms is positive.
- **(Œ¥¬†/¬†4)¬†C‚Å¥** ‚Äî quartic term that grows rapidly for large |C|.  A positive Œ¥ guarantees that the potential dominates for large C, making ‚Ñ¶ bounded below.
- **‚Ñè_C¬†|Œ®_C|¬≤** ‚Äî quantum term, proportional to the magnitude squared of the communication field.  ‚Ñè_C is an effective Planck constant; this term is always non‚Äênegative.
- **Œ∫¬†‚Äñ‚àáŒ®_C‚Äñ¬≤** ‚Äî gradient (kinetic) energy of the communication field.  Œ∫¬†>¬†0 ensures contributions from spatial variations are penalised.
- **(Œ≤¬†œÉ¬†/¬†2)¬†C¬≤** ‚Äî another quadratic contribution arising from strategic interactions (Œ† term in the original specification).  Œ≤¬†œÉ¬†>¬†0 contributes to overall convexity and can encode interaction strength.

### Parameter constraints

For Œ© to be bounded below and suitable as a Lyapunov function, choose parameters such that:

* Œ¥¬†>¬†0 ‚Äî the quartic term must be strictly positive to dominate growth for large |C|.
* Œ±¬†+¬†Œ≤¬†œÉ¬†>¬†0 ‚Äî the sum of quadratic coefficients must be positive to ensure convexity near C¬†=¬†0.
* Œ∫¬†>¬†0 and ‚Ñè_C¬†>¬†0 ‚Äî both the gradient and quantum terms must be positive.
* œÉ¬†>¬†0 ‚Äî the strategic interaction scaling should not change sign.

### Dynamical principle

To enforce that the Omega functional decreases monotonically in time, implement a
gradient‚Äêflow or proximal update rule.  In continuous time, the system evolves
according to

\[
\dot{C} = -k_C \frac{\partial \Omega}{\partial C},
\quad
\frac{\partial\Psi_C}{\partial t} = -k_\Psi\,\frac{\delta \Omega}{\delta \Psi_C^*},
\]

with positive coefficients k_C and k_Œ®.  One can also use a discrete proximal step
\(x_{t+1} = \arg\min_x \Omega(x) + \tfrac{1}{2\eta}\|x - x_t\|^2\)
to guarantee monotonic decrease in Œ©.  See the Phase¬†3 plan for details.

### Purpose

This minimal specification provides a starting point for simulations and
experimental validation.  It captures the key contributions from energy,
information, field dynamics and strategic interactions in a way that remains
mathematically well behaved.  Later phases will nondimensionalise these
quantities and connect them to measured observables.

# Units and Symbols Specification

This document defines the fundamental variables, their meanings, and the units used in the
minimal Omega equilibrium functional.  Standardising units up front helps avoid mistakes
when writing code or conducting experiments.  See `omega_project/spec/omega_minimal.md`
for the functional itself.

| Symbol      | Description                                  | Typical units                 | Notes |
|------------:|----------------------------------------------|-------------------------------|------|
| **Œ©**        | Unity equilibrium functional (the system‚Äôs Lyapunov function) | Joule (J) | By construction Œ© has units of energy. |
| **E**        | Total energy injected into or available to the system | Joule (J) | Acts as a driving term in Œ©. |
| **C**        | Communication flux ‚Äì power per unit area carried by signals | J¬∑s‚Åª¬π¬∑m‚Åª¬≤ | C represents the instantaneous flux of communication energy; multiply by a reference area and time to convert into joules. |
| **S‚Ççcomm‚Çé**  | Entropy rate of the communication channel | bit¬∑s‚Åª¬π | To convert to power units multiply by  k_B T ln¬†2 , where k_B is Boltzmann‚Äôs constant and T is an effective temperature. |
| **I‚Ççsem‚Çé**   | Semantic information rate ‚Äì number of meaningful bits per second | bit¬∑s‚Åª¬π | Measures semantic content; calibration maps improvements (e.g. accuracy gains) onto bits. |
| **Œª‚Ä≤**        | Fraction of bits that are semantically meaningful | dimensionless | Defined on [0,1]. |
| **‚Ñè_C**       | Effective Planck constant associated with the communication field | Joule | We treat ‚Ñè_C as a positive constant weighting the quantum term. |
| **Œ®_C**       | Complex amplitude of the communication field | dimensionless | A field defined over space‚Äìtime; its magnitude squared appears in Œ©. |
| **Œ±, Œ≤, Œ¥, Œ∫, œÉ** | Coefficients in the stabilising potential | variable | Chosen such that Œ© is bounded below (see `omega_minimal.md`). |
| **‚àáŒ®_C**      | Spatial gradient of the communication field | per¬†metre | Appears in gradient energy term. |

### Unit conversion

To relate information units to energy, we use Landauer‚Äôs principle: one bit of information
erasure at temperature¬†T costs E_bit¬†=¬†k_B¬†T¬†ln¬†2 joules.  When computing
terms like C¬†¬∑¬†(S_comm¬†‚Äì¬†Œª‚Ä≤¬†I_sem), convert the bit rates into power
using this factor.  The choice of T depends on the physical or effective
environment (for example ambient temperature for thermal systems, or an effective noise
temperature for electronics/AI systems).

### Recommended reference scales

To nondimensionalise the equations in later phases, choose reference scales
E‚ÇÄ,¬†C‚ÇÄ,¬†S‚ÇÄ¬†and¬†I‚ÇÄ.  Define dimensionless variables as
\tilde{E}¬†=¬†E/E‚ÇÄ, \tilde{C}¬†=¬†C/C‚ÇÄ, \tilde{S}¬†=¬†S_comm/S‚ÇÄ and \tilde{I}¬†=¬†I_sem/I‚ÇÄ.
Calibrating these scales will be part of Phase¬†1.

# üîπ Source: file_13.md

# Bit Energy and Measurement Protocol

This document describes how to convert information rates measured in bits per second
into physical energy units and proposes protocols for estimating the entropy rate
\(S_{\rm comm}\) and the semantic information rate \(I_{\rm sem}\).

## Landauer‚Äôs principle

Under Landauer‚Äôs principle, erasing one bit of information at temperature \(T\)
requires a minimum energy

\[
E_{\rm bit} = k_B \; T \; \ln 2,
\]

where \(k_B \approx 1.380649 \times 10^{-23}\)¬†J¬∑K‚Åª¬π is Boltzmann‚Äôs constant.  When
computing the coupling term \(C\,(S_{\rm comm} - \lambda'\,I_{\rm sem})\) in the
Omega functional, the bit rates should be multiplied by this factor to obtain
equivalent power (joules per second).

### Choice of temperature \(T\)

The effective temperature \(T\) depends on the physical context:

* **Thermal/physical systems:** use the ambient or operating temperature (e.g. 300¬†K for room temperature or the temperature of the heat bath in an experiment).
* **Electronic/AI systems:** define an effective noise temperature reflecting thermal noise in circuits or the environment; in practice, one can use the physical temperature of the hardware performing the computation.
* **Sociotechnical systems:** it may be convenient to select a reference temperature (e.g. 300¬†K) purely for scaling, acknowledging that the energy interpretation is metaphorical.

For consistency, specify the chosen temperature in `configs/nondim.yaml` under the key `T`.

## Measuring \(S_{\rm comm}\) (entropy rate)

The entropy rate of a communication channel quantifies the average uncertainty per unit time.  To estimate \(S_{\rm comm}\):

1. **Collect raw signal data** from the channel over a window of length \(\Delta t\).  The signal could be a sequence of symbols, bits or continuous values.
2. **Estimate probability distributions:** If the signal is discrete, estimate the probability of each symbol.  For continuous signals, discretise or estimate the differential entropy.
3. **Compute the entropy rate:** Use
   \[
   S_{\rm comm} = - \sum_i p_i \log_2 p_i
   \]
   bits per symbol and then multiply by the symbol rate (symbols per second) to obtain bits per second.
4. **Map to energy:** Multiply the resulting bit rate by \(k_B T \ln 2\) to obtain an energy rate.

## Measuring \(I_{\rm sem}\) (semantic information rate)

Semantic information measures how many of the transmitted bits are meaningful for accomplishing a task.  Estimation methods depend on context:

* **Machine learning/AI:** Compute the mutual information between input data and labels or between successive model states.  For example, one can estimate the mutual information gain when adding data in a federated learning setting and map this to bits using established estimators (e.g. variational mutual information estimators).
* **Human communication/social systems:** Score messages against a task‚Äêspecific ontology or taxonomy to assign each bit a relevance score.  Aggregate the scores over time to estimate the rate of meaningful bits.

After estimating \(I_{\rm sem}\) in bits per second, multiply by the same energy factor to express its energetic equivalent.

## Deliverables for Phase¬†1

As part of Phase¬†1, we will implement a Python script `scripts/nondim.py` that reads
reference scales from `configs/nondim.yaml` and computes dimensionless
variables.  Unit tests in `tests/test_nondim.py` will verify that the conversions
work as expected.

2. **Estimate probability distributions:** If the signal is discrete, estimate the probability of each symbol.  For continuous signals, discretise or estimate the differential entropy.
3. **Compute the entropy rate:** Use
   \[
   S_{\rm comm} = - \sum_i p_i \log_2 p_i
   \]
   bits per symbol and then multiply by the symbol rate (symbols per second) to obtain bits per second.
4. **Map to energy:** Multiply the resulting bit rate by \(k_B T \ln 2\) to obtain an energy rate.

## Measuring \(I_{\rm sem}\) (semantic information rate)

Semantic information measures how many of the transmitted bits are meaningful for accomplishing a task.  Estimation methods depend on context:

* **Machine learning/AI:** Compute the mutual information between input data and labels or between successive model states.  For example, one can estimate the mutual information gain when adding data in a federated learning setting and map this to bits using established estimators (e.g. variational mutual information estimators).
* **Human communication/social systems:** Score messages against a task‚Äêspecific ontology or taxonomy to assign each bit a relevance score.  Aggregate the scores over time to estimate the rate of meaningful bits.

After estimating \(I_{\rm sem}\) in bits per second, multiply by the same energy factor to express its energetic equivalent.

## Deliverables for Phase¬†1

As part of Phase¬†1, we will implement a Python script `scripts/nondim.py` that reads
reference scales from `configs/nondim.yaml` and computes dimensionless
variables.  Unit tests in `tests/test_nondim.py` will verify that the conversions
work as expected.

# Minimal Stable Omega Functional

This document describes the minimal form of the ‚Ñ¶ (Omega) functional that is
bounded below and suitable for gradient‚Äìflow dynamics.  The goal is to combine
thermodynamic, informational and field-theoretic contributions into a single
Lyapunov‚Äêlike function for complex systems.  A stable form ensures that the
functional does not run off to negative infinity and can serve as a
Lyapunov function for dynamical evolution.

## Functional definition

We propose the following form for the Omega functional:

\[
\Omega = E \; - \; C\,\bigl(S_{\mathrm{comm}} - \lambda'\,I_{\mathrm{sem}}\bigr)
\; + \; \tfrac{\alpha}{2} C^2
\; + \; \tfrac{\delta}{4} C^4
\; + \; \hbar_C |\Psi_C|^2
\; + \; \kappa\,\Vert\nabla \Psi_C\Vert^2
\; + \; \tfrac{\beta\sigma}{2}\,C^2.
\]

### Terms

- **E** ‚Äî total energy available to or injected into the system.
- **C¬†(S_comm¬†‚àí¬†Œª‚Ä≤¬†I_sem)** ‚Äî coupling between communication flux and the entropy/semantic information content of the channel.  The term penalises high entropy and rewards meaningful information, weighted by the fraction Œª‚Ä≤ of bits carrying semantics.
- **(Œ±¬†/¬†2)¬†C¬≤** ‚Äî quadratic contribution to the potential.  This term, combined with Œ≤œÉC¬≤ below, ensures convexity near the origin.  The coefficients are tuned such that the sum of quadratic terms is positive.
- **(Œ¥¬†/¬†4)¬†C‚Å¥** ‚Äî quartic term that grows rapidly for large |C|.  A positive Œ¥ guarantees that the potential dominates for large C, making ‚Ñ¶ bounded below.
- **‚Ñè_C¬†|Œ®_C|¬≤** ‚Äî quantum term, proportional to the magnitude squared of the communication field.  ‚Ñè_C is an effective Planck constant; this term is always non‚Äênegative.
- **Œ∫¬†‚Äñ‚àáŒ®_C‚Äñ¬≤** ‚Äî gradient (kinetic) energy of the communication field.  Œ∫¬†>¬†0 ensures contributions from spatial variations are penalised.
- **(Œ≤¬†œÉ¬†/¬†2)¬†C¬≤** ‚Äî another quadratic contribution arising from strategic interactions (Œ† term in the original specification).  Œ≤¬†œÉ¬†>¬†0 contributes to overall convexity and can encode interaction strength.

### Parameter constraints

For Œ© to be bounded below and suitable as a Lyapunov function, choose parameters such that:

* Œ¥¬†>¬†0 ‚Äî the quartic term must be strictly positive to dominate growth for large |C|.
* Œ±¬†+¬†Œ≤¬†œÉ¬†>¬†0 ‚Äî the sum of quadratic coefficients must be positive to ensure convexity near C¬†=¬†0.
* Œ∫¬†>¬†0 and ‚Ñè_C¬†>¬†0 ‚Äî both the gradient and quantum terms must be positive.
* œÉ¬†>¬†0 ‚Äî the strategic interaction scaling should not change sign.

### Dynamical principle

To enforce that the Omega functional decreases monotonically in time, implement a
gradient‚Äêflow or proximal update rule.  In continuous time, the system evolves
according to

\[
\dot{C} = -k_C \frac{\partial \Omega}{\partial C},
\quad
\frac{\partial\Psi_C}{\partial t} = -k_\Psi\,\frac{\delta \Omega}{\delta \Psi_C^*},
\]

with positive coefficients k_C and k_Œ®.  One can also use a discrete proximal step
\(x_{t+1} = \arg\min_x \Omega(x) + \tfrac{1}{2\eta}\|x - x_t\|^2\)
to guarantee monotonic decrease in Œ©.  See the Phase¬†3 plan for details.

experimental validation.  It captures the key contributions from energy,
information, field dynamics and strategic interactions in a way that remains
mathematically well behaved.  Later phases will nondimensionalise these
quantities and connect them to measured observables.

# Bit Energy and Measurement Protocol

This document describes how to convert information rates measured in bits per second
into physical energy units and proposes protocols for estimating the entropy rate
\(S_{\rm comm}\) and the semantic information rate \(I_{\rm sem}\).

## Landauer‚Äôs principle

Under Landauer‚Äôs principle, erasing one bit of information at temperature \(T\)
requires a minimum energy

\[
E_{\rm bit} = k_B \; T \; \ln 2,
\]

where \(k_B \approx 1.380649 \times 10^{-23}\)¬†J¬∑K‚Åª¬π is Boltzmann‚Äôs constant.  When
computing the coupling term \(C\,(S_{\rm comm} - \lambda'\,I_{\rm sem})\) in the
Omega functional, the bit rates should be multiplied by this factor to obtain
equivalent power (joules per second).

### Choice of temperature \(T\)

The effective temperature \(T\) depends on the physical context:

* **Thermal/physical systems:** use the ambient or operating temperature (e.g. 300¬†K for room temperature or the temperature of the heat bath in an experiment).
* **Electronic/AI systems:** define an effective noise temperature reflecting thermal noise in circuits or the environment; in practice, one can use the physical temperature of the hardware performing the computation.
* **Sociotechnical systems:** it may be convenient to select a reference temperature (e.g. 300¬†K) purely for scaling, acknowledging that the energy interpretation is metaphorical.

For consistency, specify the chosen temperature in `configs/nondim.yaml` under the key `T`.

## Measuring \(S_{\rm comm}\) (entropy rate)

The entropy rate of a communication channel quantifies the average uncertainty per unit time.  To estimate \(S_{\rm comm}\):

1. **Collect raw signal data** from the channel over a window of length \(\Delta t\).  The signal could be a sequence of symbols, bits or continuous values.
2. **Estimate probability distributions:** If the signal is discrete, estimate the probability of each symbol.  For continuous signals, discretise or estimate the differential entropy.
3. **Compute the entropy rate:** Use
   \[
   S_{\rm comm} = - \sum_i p_i \log_2 p_i
   \]
   bits per symbol and then multiply by the symbol rate (symbols per second) to obtain bits per second.
4. **Map to energy:** Multiply the resulting bit rate by \(k_B T \ln 2\) to obtain an energy rate.

## Measuring \(I_{\rm sem}\) (semantic information rate)

Semantic information measures how many of the transmitted bits are meaningful for accomplishing a task.  Estimation methods depend on context:

* **Machine learning/AI:** Compute the mutual information between input data and labels or between successive model states.  For example, one can estimate the mutual information gain when adding data in a federated learning setting and map this to bits using established estimators (e.g. variational mutual information estimators).
* **Human communication/social systems:** Score messages against a task‚Äêspecific ontology or taxonomy to assign each bit a relevance score.  Aggregate the scores over time to estimate the rate of meaningful bits.

After estimating \(I_{\rm sem}\) in bits per second, multiply by the same energy factor to express its energetic equivalent.

## Deliverables for Phase¬†1

As part of Phase¬†1, we will implement a Python script `scripts/nondim.py` that reads
reference scales from `configs/nondim.yaml` and computes dimensionless
variables.  Unit tests in `tests/test_nondim.py` will verify that the conversions
work as expected.

# Phase¬†6 AI: Measurement and Calibration

## Background

Training modern machine‚Äëlearning models consumes significant energy, and measuring that consumption is a prerequisite for quantifying the energetic cost of information processing. Several software and hardware tools exist for estimating the energy and carbon footprint of AI workloads. These range from integrated Python packages to server‚Äëside monitoring systems and physical wattmeters. The Œ© framework links energy use to information: the entropy rate of the communication channel ScommS_{\rm comm}Scomm‚Äã and the semantic information rate IsemI_{\rm sem}Isem‚Äã must be measured alongside the energy used to process data and train models.

## Measuring Energy Consumption

Research from Bouza et¬†al. (2023) reviews tools that measure or estimate energy consumption and CO‚ÇÇ‚Äëequivalent emissions for deep‚Äëlearning models[pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10661046/#:~:text=This%20section%20explains%20how%20tools,own%20way%20of%20estimating%20the). These tools fall into three categories:

- **Embedded software packages (Python libraries).** Packages such as CodeCarbon, Eco2AI, CarbonTracker, EIT and MLCO‚ÇÇ can be integrated into machine‚Äëlearning code to estimate the energy used by CPUs, GPUs and memory. They obtain power measurements from hardware sensors (e.g. RAPL files or the NVIDIA `pynvml` interface) or fall back to thermal design power (TDP) models when sensors are unavailable[pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10661046/#:~:text=5,yes%20yes%20yes%20no%20no). Measurements are taken at regular intervals (typically every 10‚Äì15¬†s) to compute the average power draw[pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10661046/#:~:text=A%20transversal%20concept%20to%20all,processes%20also%20using%20said%20resource).
    
- **Online calculators and server‚Äëside tools.** Tools like Green‚ÄëAlgorithms provide web forms or server‚Äëside daemons that estimate total energy consumption for a job or a machine. These tools can be used without modifying code and are useful in high‚Äëperformance computing environments[pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10661046/#:~:text=This%20section%20explains%20how%20tools,own%20way%20of%20estimating%20the).
    
- **Physical wattmeters.** When more precise measurements are required, wattmeters can be attached to the power supply of a machine to capture the total energy draw. Physical measurements can be combined with usage factors‚Äîthe proportion of CPU/GPU use attributable to a given process‚Äîto allocate energy consumption to specific training runs[pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10661046/#:~:text=A%20transversal%20concept%20to%20all,processes%20also%20using%20said%20resource).
    

Additional factors include the efficiency of the data center where training occurs. The power‚Äëusage effectiveness (PUE) quantifies how much extra energy is needed for cooling, lighting and other overhead; some tools allow users to configure PUE values[pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10661046/#:~:text=When%20the%20machine%20is%20in,PUE). When models are trained in cloud environments, the energy used by shared infrastructure must be attributed appropriately using usage factors[pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10661046/#:~:text=A%20transversal%20concept%20to%20all,processes%20also%20using%20said%20resource).

## Measuring Semantic Information

The semantic gain of a model can be quantified using mutual information. Mutual information I(X;Y)I(X;Y)I(X;Y) between random variables XXX and YYY is defined as the Kullback‚ÄìLeibler divergence between their joint distribution and the product of their marginals[en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutual_information#:~:text=Mutual%20Information%20is%20also%20known,as%20information%20gain). In terms of entropy, I(X;Y)=H(X)‚àíH(X‚à£Y)=H(Y)‚àíH(Y‚à£X)I(X;Y) = H(X) - H(X|Y) = H(Y) - H(Y|X)I(X;Y)=H(X)‚àíH(X‚à£Y)=H(Y)‚àíH(Y‚à£X)[en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutual_information#:~:text=%5BImage%2027%3A%20%7B%5Cdisplaystyle%20I%28X%3BY%29%3DH%28X%29). For discrete variables, mutual information is computed by summing PX,Y(x,y)log‚Å°(PX,Y(x,y)/(PX(x)PY(y)))P_{X,Y}(x,y) \log \big(P_{X,Y}(x,y)/(P_X(x) P_Y(y))\big)PX,Y‚Äã(x,y)log(PX,Y‚Äã(x,y)/(PX‚Äã(x)PY‚Äã(y))) over all pairs (x,y)(x,y)(x,y)[en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutual_information#:~:text=,3%20%5D%3A%2020). When the log base¬†2 is used, the result is measured in bits[en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutual_information#:~:text=If%20the%20natural%20logarithm%20,as%20the%20ban%20or%20the).

In the AI domain, IsemI_{\rm sem}Isem‚Äã can represent the reduction in uncertainty about labels given the model‚Äôs predictions or the gain in performance on a downstream task. To estimate IsemI_{\rm sem}Isem‚Äã one may:

- **Compute mutual information between inputs and labels** using kernel density estimators or discrete histograms. This measures how much the model‚Äôs updates (or communication between federated learners) convey about the training labels.
    
- **Use task‚Äëspecific metrics (e.g. accuracy or F1‚Äëscore)** and convert performance improvements into bits via Fano‚Äôs inequality or surrogate mutual‚Äëinformation estimators.
    
- **Assess semantic alignment in generative models** by computing the mutual information between generated outputs and desired semantics.
    

The raw communication entropy rate ScommS_{\rm comm}Scomm‚Äã corresponds to the bit rate of data exchanged (e.g. gradients or model parameters) and is measured by counting transmitted bits per unit time. Landauer‚Äôs principle then maps each erased bit to an energy cost of kBTln‚Å°2k_B T\ln 2kB‚ÄãTln2 joules.

## Proposed Measurement Procedure

1. **Instrumentation.** Integrate a measurement package (e.g. CodeCarbon) into the training code or set up a monitoring daemon on the training server. Ensure the package can access CPU/GPU sensors or provide TDP models. Configure the sampling interval (e.g. 10¬†s)[pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10661046/#:~:text=A%20transversal%20concept%20to%20all,processes%20also%20using%20said%20resource) and set the appropriate PUE factor if training in a data center[pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10661046/#:~:text=When%20the%20machine%20is%20in,PUE).
    
2. **Record energy.** Start the measurement before training begins. At each sampling interval, record the instantaneous power consumption of CPU, GPU and memory. Multiply power by the interval length to obtain energy (Wh) and sum over time to get total energy consumption for the training run.
    
3. **Calculate usage factors.** When multiple processes run on the same hardware, compute the fraction of each resource used by the training job (e.g. CPU utilization) and scale the measured power accordingly[pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10661046/#:~:text=A%20transversal%20concept%20to%20all,processes%20also%20using%20said%20resource). If usage factors are unknown, assume 100% as a conservative upper bound.
    
4. **Measure communication entropy ScommS_{\rm comm}Scomm‚Äã.** For federated or distributed training, log the size (in bits) of gradients or parameters transmitted per round and divide by the time between rounds to obtain the bit rate. Convert to entropy rate by accounting for compression schemes and error‚Äëcorrecting overhead.
    
5. **Measure semantic information IsemI_{\rm sem}Isem‚Äã.** After each training round or epoch, estimate the mutual information between the model parameters (or predictions) and the ground‚Äëtruth labels using the methods described above. Record the information gain per unit time.
    
6. **Compute Œ© and calibrate Œª‚Ä≤.** Convert the bit rates to energy rates via Landauer‚Äôs principle. Plug the measured values into Œ©=E‚àíC(Scomm‚àíŒª‚Ä≤Isem)+‚Ä¶\Omega = E - C(S_{\rm comm} - \lambda' I_{\rm sem}) + \dotsŒ©=E‚àíC(Scomm‚Äã‚àíŒª‚Ä≤Isem‚Äã)+‚Ä¶ and adjust Œª‚Ä≤ and other parameters so that the experimental trajectory of Œ© matches the model‚Äôs predictions. Use parameter sweeps and gradient‚Äëbased optimization to identify values that ensure dŒ©/dt‚â§0\mathrm{d}\Omega/\mathrm{d}t \le 0dŒ©/dt‚â§0.
    

## Calibration Notes

Because the energy measurement tools differ in their precision and assumptions, it is advisable to cross‚Äëvalidate results. For example, compare CodeCarbon‚Äôs estimates with readings from a physical wattmeter. When training in cloud environments, obtain PUE and emission‚Äëfactor data from the provider. Finally, ensure that any privacy‚Äësensitive information is anonymized or aggregated before computing mutual information.

# Phase¬†6 Social: Measurement and Calibration

## Background

Digital social platforms enable billions of interactions every day. Behind each post, video stream or message is a network of servers and data centers that consume electricity. Articles on the environmental cost of social media note that platforms like Facebook, Instagram and TikTok rely on data‚Äëcenter infrastructure powered by electricity, much of which is generated from carbon‚Äëintensive sources[greenly.earth](https://greenly.earth/en-us/leaf-media/data-stories/the-hidden-environmental-cost-of-social-media#:~:text=Social%20media%20has%20transformed%20the,to%20keep%20these%20platforms%20running). Every digital action therefore contributes to global emissions[greenly.earth](https://greenly.earth/en-us/leaf-media/data-stories/the-hidden-environmental-cost-of-social-media#:~:text=environmental%20cost%3A%20the%20energy%20required,to%20keep%20these%20platforms%20running). More broadly, U.S. data centers consumed about 183¬†TWh of electricity in¬†2024‚Äîover 4% of national demand‚Äîand this consumption is expected to more than double by 2030[pewresearch.org](https://www.pewresearch.org/short-reads/2025/10/24/what-we-know-about-energy-use-at-us-data-centers-amid-the-ai-boom/#:~:text=U,to%20426%20TWh). Around 60% of a data center‚Äôs electricity powers servers, particularly the powerful chips used for AI workloads[pewresearch.org](https://www.pewresearch.org/short-reads/2025/10/24/what-we-know-about-energy-use-at-us-data-centers-amid-the-ai-boom/#:~:text=,for%20at%20data%20centers).

Social interactions not only require energy but also produce and exchange information. When users share high‚Äëquality, semantically meaningful content, they may cooperate more and the system may perform more useful work per unit energy. The Œ© framework models these dynamics via the communication flux CCC, communication entropy rate ScommS_{\rm comm}Scomm‚Äã and semantic information rate IsemI_{\rm sem}Isem‚Äã.

## Measuring Energy Consumption in Social Systems

To study Œ© in a social context, one needs to measure how much energy is consumed by the platform and by end‚Äëusers. At the platform level, energy use can be estimated by combining data‚Äëcenter energy metrics with user activity:

- **Data‚Äëcenter energy statistics.** Obtain server‚Äëlevel power measurements from the platform provider. The Pew Research Center reports that data centers use 60¬†% of their electricity to power servers[pewresearch.org](https://www.pewresearch.org/short-reads/2025/10/24/what-we-know-about-energy-use-at-us-data-centers-amid-the-ai-boom/#:~:text=,for%20at%20data%20centers); remaining energy powers cooling and other infrastructure. Consumption per user or per interaction can be estimated by dividing total server energy by the number of active users or requests.
    
- **User‚Äëside energy.** Recognize that users themselves consume energy when accessing social platforms. The Hidden Environmental Cost of Social Media notes that emissions come not only from corporate operations but also from the energy used by billions of users when they stream videos or run power‚Äëhungry devices[greenly.earth](https://greenly.earth/en-us/leaf-media/data-stories/the-hidden-environmental-cost-of-social-media#:~:text=In%20response%2C%20many%20of%20the,intensive%20devices%20such%20as%20laptops). Approximate user‚Äëside energy by measuring average device power consumption during platform use and scaling by session duration.
    

## Proposed Experiment for the Social Domain

The following A/B‚Äëstyle experiment can be conducted within a social platform to test how information quality affects cooperation and energy use:

1. **Participant groups.** Recruit users or simulate agents on a social platform. Randomly assign them to two groups (A¬†and¬†B). Group¬†A receives high‚Äëquality, semantically rich information streams, while group¬†B receives lower‚Äëquality or noisy information.
    
2. **Instrumentation.** Instrument the platform‚Äôs backend to log energy use per request. Use server monitoring tools to record total energy consumption and allocate it to groups based on the number of requests they generate. At the same time, instrument client devices (or estimate typical device power) to approximate user‚Äëside energy consumption for each session.
    
3. **Measure communication entropy.** For each group, record the total amount of data exchanged (posts, messages, video minutes) over time. Compute ScommS_{\rm comm}Scomm‚Äã by converting data volume to bits per second and adjusting for compression or protocol overhead.
    
4. **Measure semantic information and cooperation.** Assess the semantic quality of content using mutual information or natural‚Äëlanguage metrics (e.g. topic relevance, factual accuracy). Quantify cooperative behaviour via metrics such as the number of constructive comments, successful collaborations or completion of shared tasks.
    
5. **Compute Œ© and compare groups.** For each group, calculate energy used (servers¬†+ clients), communication entropy rate and semantic information rate. Use these to compute Œ©=E‚àíC(Scomm‚àíŒª‚Ä≤Isem)+‚Ä¶\Omega = E - C(S_{\rm comm}-\lambda' I_{\rm sem}) + \dotsŒ©=E‚àíC(Scomm‚Äã‚àíŒª‚Ä≤Isem‚Äã)+‚Ä¶. If the Œ© framework is correct, the group receiving higher‚Äëquality information should exhibit lower Œ© (more cooperation and semantic efficiency) and Œ© should decrease over time as users align their actions.
    

## Calibration and Parameter Extraction

After collecting data, estimate Œª‚Ä≤ as the ratio of semantic information to raw communication entropy: Œª‚Ä≤=Isem/Scomm\lambda' = I_{\rm sem}/S_{\rm comm}Œª‚Ä≤=Isem‚Äã/Scomm‚Äã. Fit other Œ© parameters using gradient‚Äëbased methods to ensure that the model reproduces the observed decline of Œ© in the high‚Äëquality information group. This experiment will also reveal how improvements in content quality or platform efficiency (e.g. migrating to renewable energy) reduce energy consumption per meaningful interaction.

# Phase¬†6 Thermo: Measurement and Calibration

## Background

Heat moves from hotter objects to colder ones, and the rate of energy transfer per unit area and unit time is called the heat flux. Fourier‚Äôs law states that the flux is proportional to the negative of the temperature gradient; in one dimension the law reads œïq=‚àíkdTdx\phi_q = -k \frac{\mathrm{d}T}{\mathrm{d}x}œïq‚Äã=‚àíkdxdT‚Äã, where kkk is the thermal conductivity of the material[en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heat_flux#:~:text=For%20most%20solids%20%20in,adequately%20described%20by%20Fourier%27s%20law). Measuring heat flux is important because it determines how much energy is exchanged between systems and therefore how their entropy changes. The entropy change of a system due to a heat transfer QQQ at temperature TTT is ŒîS=Q/T\Delta S = Q/TŒîS=Q/T; for processes with small temperature variations this approximation holds well[physics.bu.edu](https://physics.bu.edu/~redner/211-sp06/class-engines/class25_secondlaw.html#:~:text=Entropy%20changes%20whenever%20there%20is,Expressed%20as%20an%20integral). In the toy Œ©‚Äëmodel, heat transfer and entropy production correspond to the communication term C(Scomm‚àíŒª‚Ä≤Isem)C(S_{\rm comm}-\lambda' I_{\rm sem})C(Scomm‚Äã‚àíŒª‚Ä≤Isem‚Äã), so obtaining reliable flux and entropy measurements is essential for calibrating Œª‚Ä≤.

## Heat‚ÄëFlux Measurement Methods

1. **Known thermal conductivity.** When the thermal conductivity kkk and thickness xxx of a material are known, one can measure the temperature difference across the material and use Fourier‚Äôs law to compute the heat flux. This indirect method is analogous to measuring an electric current via a known resistor: by measuring the temperature drop across a known thermal resistance, one obtains the flux[en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heat_flux#:~:text=A%20commonly%20known%2C%20but%20often,can%20then%20be%20indirectly%20calculated). Accurate values of kkk and xxx are required, which can be difficult for heterogeneous materials[en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heat_flux#:~:text=Usually%20this%20method%20is%20difficult,flux%20can%20then%20be%20indirectly).
    
2. **Unknown thermal conductivity.** When kkk is unknown or impractical to measure, a heat‚Äëflux sensor (often a thermopile) can be used to directly measure the energy flow. Such sensors produce a voltage proportional to the temperature difference across a calibrated thermal resistance and therefore provide heat‚Äëflux readings without needing kkk[en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heat_flux#:~:text=A%20second%20method%20of%20measuring,value%20of%20thermal%20resistance%20or). The sensor output must be calibrated to relate the micro‚Äëvolt signal to heat flux in W‚Äâm‚àí2\mathrm{W\,m^{-2}}Wm‚àí2[en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heat_flux#:~:text=A%20second%20method%20of%20measuring,value%20of%20thermal%20resistance%20or).
    

## Entropy‚ÄëChange Calculation

Entropy is a state function, but its change is easy to compute when heat flows at (or near) a constant temperature. For a small amount of heat transfer dQ\mathrm{d}QdQ at temperature TTT, the entropy change is dS=dQ/T\mathrm{d}S = \mathrm{d}Q/TdS=dQ/T. Integrating yields ŒîS=Q/Tavg\Delta S = Q/T_{\rm avg}ŒîS=Q/Tavg‚Äã when the temperature varies only slightly during the exchange[physics.bu.edu](https://physics.bu.edu/~redner/211-sp06/class-engines/class25_secondlaw.html#:~:text=Entropy%20changes%20whenever%20there%20is,Expressed%20as%20an%20integral). In the two‚Äëbody problem (e.g. two water containers), the entropy increase in the colder body is ŒîScold=Q/Tcold\Delta S_{\rm cold} = Q/T_{\rm cold}ŒîScold‚Äã=Q/Tcold‚Äã and the entropy decrease in the hotter body is ‚àíQ/Thot-Q/T_{\rm hot}‚àíQ/Thot‚Äã; summing them gives the net entropy production of the process[physics.bu.edu](https://physics.bu.edu/~redner/211-sp06/class-engines/class25_secondlaw.html#:~:text=Entropy%20changes%20whenever%20there%20is,Expressed%20as%20an%20integral).

## Proposed Measurement Procedure

The following procedure translates the above ideas into a repeatable experiment for calibrating the Œ© model in a thermal context.

1. **Experimental setup.** Prepare two bodies (e.g. water containers) at different initial temperatures T1>T2T_1 > T_2T1‚Äã>T2‚Äã. Place a heat‚Äëflux sensor between them or insert a slab of known material with temperature sensors on both sides. Record the contact area AAA and the duration of the experiment Œît\Delta tŒît.
    
2. **Calibrate the sensor.** If using a heat‚Äëflux sensor, perform a calibration using a known flux or rely on the manufacturer‚Äôs calibration to map voltage (¬µV) to W‚Äâm‚àí2\mathrm{W\,m^{-2}}Wm‚àí2[en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heat_flux#:~:text=A%20second%20method%20of%20measuring,value%20of%20thermal%20resistance%20or). For the resistor method, determine the slab‚Äôs thermal conductivity kkk and thickness xxx in advance[en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heat_flux#:~:text=A%20commonly%20known%2C%20but%20often,can%20then%20be%20indirectly%20calculated).
    
3. **Measure temperature gradient and flux.** During the experiment, continuously record the temperature difference ŒîT(t)\Delta T(t)ŒîT(t) across the interface. Compute the instantaneous heat flux œïq(t)\phi_q(t)œïq‚Äã(t) using Fourier‚Äôs law (‚àíkŒîT/x-k \Delta T/x‚àíkŒîT/x) or read it directly from the sensor. Integrate œïq(t)\phi_q(t)œïq‚Äã(t) over area and time to obtain the total heat transferred Q=‚à´0Œîtœïq(t)A‚ÄâdtQ = \int_0^{\Delta t} \phi_q(t) A\,\mathrm{d}tQ=‚à´0Œît‚Äãœïq‚Äã(t)Adt.
    
4. **Compute entropy change.** Estimate the average temperatures of both bodies over the interaction period (T1,avgT_{1,\rm avg}T1,avg‚Äã and T2,avgT_{2,\rm avg}T2,avg‚Äã). Compute ŒîS1=‚àíQ/T1,avg\Delta S_1 = -Q/T_{1,\rm avg}ŒîS1‚Äã=‚àíQ/T1,avg‚Äã and ŒîS2=Q/T2,avg\Delta S_2 = Q/T_{2,\rm avg}ŒîS2‚Äã=Q/T2,avg‚Äã. The net entropy production is ŒîStotal=ŒîS1+ŒîS2\Delta S_{\rm total} = \Delta S_1 + \Delta S_2ŒîStotal‚Äã=ŒîS1‚Äã+ŒîS2‚Äã[physics.bu.edu](https://physics.bu.edu/~redner/211-sp06/class-engines/class25_secondlaw.html#:~:text=Entropy%20changes%20whenever%20there%20is,Expressed%20as%20an%20integral).
    
5. **Map to Œ© variables.** Treat the measured heat flux per unit area as the communication flux CCC in the Œ© model. Convert the entropy rate dS/dt\mathrm{d}S/\mathrm{d}tdS/dt to bits per second via Scomm=(ŒîS/Œît)/(kBTln‚Å°2)S_{\rm comm} = (\Delta S/\Delta t) / (k_B T \ln 2)Scomm‚Äã=(ŒîS/Œît)/(kB‚ÄãTln2). If the experiment involves information being transmitted (e.g. digital signals), measure the mutual information IsemI_{\rm sem}Isem‚Äã and compute the energy cost per meaningful bit. Finally, compute Œ©\OmegaŒ© at each time point and verify that it decreases toward zero as the system approaches equilibrium.
    

## Calibration and Parameter Extraction

Once heat‚Äëflux data and entropy production are obtained, one can calibrate Œª‚Ä≤ and other parameters in the Œ© model by solving C(Scomm‚àíŒª‚Ä≤Isem)C(S_{\rm comm}-\lambda' I_{\rm sem})C(Scomm‚Äã‚àíŒª‚Ä≤Isem‚Äã) to match the measured energy flow. A parameter sweep over Œ±\alphaŒ±, Œ≤\betaŒ≤, Œ¥\deltaŒ¥ and other coefficients from the minimal, stable Œ© formulation (see Phase¬†2) can then be performed to identify values that reproduce the observed decrease in Œ© over time.

# Œ© Project User Guide

Welcome to the Œ© (_Omega_) framework. This guide explains how to set up  
the environment, run the provided scripts, interpret results and use the  
documentation site. It assumes basic familiarity with Python and the  
command line.

## 1. Installation and setup

1. **Clone or extract the repository.** If you received a ZIP archive  
    (`omega_project_phaseX.zip`), unpack it into a directory of your  
    choice.
2. **Install Python 3.11 or later.** Most scripts rely on standard  
    scientific libraries (NumPy, Matplotlib, PyYAML). You can install  
    dependencies via `pip`:
```bash
pip install numpy matplotlib pyyaml
```
3. **Set the Python path (optional).** The project uses a  
    package structure (`omega_project`). When running scripts from the  
    repository root, set the `PYTHONPATH` environment variable:

```bash
export PYTHONPATH="$(pwd)"
```


## 2. Repository structure

```bash
omega_project/
  configs/          # YAML configuration files for simulations
  data/             # Sample signal and dataset for measurement demos
  docs/             # MkDocs documentation pages
  experiments/      # Outputs from simulations and analyses
  notebooks/        # Jupyter notebooks (optional, not required)
  reports/          # Example reports from Phase¬†6
  scripts/          # Executable Python scripts
  spec/             # Formal specifications (Œ© functional, units, GR tensor)
  tests/            # Unit tests
risk_register.md    # Identified risks and mitigations
user_guide.md       # This guide
mkdocs.yml          # Configuration for documentation site
repro.sh            # Reproducibility script
```

### Key components

- **`spec/units_and_symbols.md`** defines all symbols, units and constants.
- **`spec/omega_minimal.md`** describes the minimal stable form of the Œ©  
    functional and its parameters.
- **`scripts/nondim.py`** converts variables to nondimensional form based  
    on user‚Äësupplied scales (see `configs/nondim.yaml`).
- **`scripts/entropy_rate.py`** computes the communication entropy rate  
    $S_{\rm comm}$‚Äã from a digital signal file.
- **`scripts/semantic_mi.py`** estimates the semantic information rate  
    $I_{\rm sem}‚Äã$ via mutual information between variables in a dataset.
- **`scripts/gradflow.py`** and **`scripts/prox_step.py`** perform  
    gradient and proximal dynamics for the communication flux $C$.
- **`scripts/gr_check.py`** verifies the conservation of the communication  
    stress‚Äìenergy tensor in a relativistic setting.
- **`scripts/plot_omega.py`** reads a CSV trace and produces a graph of  
    Œ© versus time.
- **`repro.sh`** orchestrates a simple reproducible experiment and plots  
    Œ©(t).
- **`docs/`** contains the documentation site; see section¬†5 for usage.
    

## 3. Measurement pipeline

1. **Prepare your data.** To compute $S_{\rm comm}‚Äã$, provide a raw  
    signal file where each sample is an integer or symbol. To compute  
    $I_{\rm sem}$‚Äã, provide a CSV file with columns representing input  
    variables and target labels.
    
2. **Compute communication entropy:**
    
```bash
python -m omega_project.scripts.entropy_rate \
  --input path/to/signal.txt \
  --sample_rate 1000 \
  --temperature 300 \
  --window 4096 \
  --output s_comm.json
```

This will estimate the entropy rate in bits per second and convert it  
to joules per second using $E_{\rm bit} = k_B T \ln 2.$ Adjust  
`sample_rate` and `temperature` to match your system.
    
3. **Compute semantic information:**
    
```bash
python -m omega_project.scripts.semantic_mi \
  --dataset path/to/dataset.csv \
  --columns X,Y \
  --bins 20 \
  --output i_sem.json
```


The script will estimate the mutual information between columns `X`  
and `Y`. Increase the number of bins for finer resolution. You can  
normalise by sample time to obtain a rate.
    
4. **Calibrate \lambda'.** Use your estimates of $S_{\rm comm}$ 
    and $I_{\rm sem}‚Äã$ to compute the ratio $Œª\lambda' = I_{\rm sem} / S_{\rm comm}.$
    Store this value in a configuration file (see `configs/calib_lambda.yaml`)  
    for use in simulations.
    

## 4. Simulating dynamics

To explore how Œ© evolves over time, run the gradient or proximal  
simulation scripts. For example:

```bash
# Gradient flow simulation
python -m omega_project.scripts.gradflow \
  --steps 200 --dt 0.01 --initial 1.0 \
  --alpha 1.0 --delta 1.0 --beta 0.5 --sigma 1.0 \
  --lambda_prime 0.001 --S_comm 0.5 --I_sem 0.4 \
  --output experiments/gradflow.csv

# Proximal gradient simulation
python -m omega_project.scripts.prox_step \
  --steps 200 --eta 0.1 --initial 1.0 \
  --alpha 1.0 --delta 1.0 --beta 0.5 --sigma 1.0 \
  --lambda_prime 0.001 --S_comm 0.5 --I_sem 0.4 \
  --output experiments/prox.csv
```

After running a simulation, you can visualise Œ©(t) using  
`scripts/plot_omega.py`:

```bash
python -m omega_project.scripts.plot_omega \
  --input experiments/gradflow.csv \
  --output experiments/omega.png
```

## 5. Documentation site

The project includes a MkDocs site that gathers specifications,  
explanations and examples. To build and preview the site locally, run:

```bash
pip install mkdocs
mkdocs serve
```

Then navigate to `http://localhost:8000` in your browser. The site  
contains pages on the Omega equation, measurement pipelines, dynamics  
and the GR tensor, along with embedded figures.

## 6. Reproducibility script

The `repro.sh` script provides a turnkey reproduction of a simple  
experiment. It runs a gradient flow with fixed parameters and  
generates a CSV and PNG plot in `omega_project/experiments/repro/`.

To execute the script from the repository root:

```bassh
bash repro.sh
```

The script sets up the Python path, runs the simulation via  
`gradflow.py` and then calls `plot_omega.py` to create `omega.png`. Check  
the resulting CSV and PNG to verify that Œ© decreases monotonically.

## 7. Additional tools

- **GR tensor check:** Verify conservation of the communication  
    stress‚Äìenergy tensor by running
  ```bash
    python -m omega_project.scripts.gr_check --n 400 --tol 1e-3
    ```
The script prints the maximum divergence and reports whether the  
conservation law holds within the specified tolerance.
    
- **Toy models:** Explore the parameter space using `run_toy.py` and  
    configuration files under `configs/`. For example:
```bash
   python -m omega_project.scripts.run_toy \
  --config omega_project/configs/minimal.yaml \
  --out experiments/sweep_results.csv
```
Review the CSV to identify parameter regimes where Œ© decreases and converges.

## 8. Data and privacy considerations

When working with real data, ensure that you anonymize or aggregate  
personal information. Researchers caution that evaluating  
re‚Äëidentification and inference risks is essential when publishing  
datasets[oaepublish.com](https://www.oaepublish.com/articles/jsss.2020.20#:~:text=Aim%3A%20Data%20anonymization%20aims%20to,publishing%20data%20with%20a%20high). If using distributed learning or  
federated settings, be aware that attackers may infer sensitive  
information from gradients; mutual information can be used to analyse  
utility‚Äìprivacy trade‚Äëoffs and to choose noise levels appropriately[pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC9498028/#:~:text=In%20distributed%20machine%20learning%20,Finally%2C%20the).

## 9. Contributing

Contributions are welcome! Please open issues or pull requests to  
propose improvements. Before submitting code, run the test suite and  
pre‚Äëcommit hooks to ensure style and stability.
